PHYS*2180 or (NANO*2100, PHYS*2310)
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PHYS*4002.Title: PHYS*4002 Research in Physics (0.5 Credits)
PHYS*4002.Description: This course is the second part of the  two-semester course PHYS*4001/2. This is a  two-semester (F-W) course in which students apply  their knowledge and skills through independent  research of an experimental or theoretical nature  within physics. Students will be required to  present their results in both oral and written  reports. Students must make arrangements with a  faculty supervisor and obtain approval of the  course co-ordinator before course selection.  Approval of the course co-ordinator will only be  granted upon receipt of a completed registration  form, available from the co-ordinator during the  course selection period. This is a two-semester  course offered over consecutive semesters. When  you select it, you must select PHYS*4001 in the  Fall semester and PHYS*4002 in the Winter  semester. A grade will not be assigned to  PHYS*4001 until PHYS*4002 has been completed.
PHYS*4002.Requisites:
PHYS*4001
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PHYS*4040.Title: PHYS*4040 Quantum Mechanics II (0.5 Credits)
PHYS*4040.Description: This is a second course in quantum mechanics.  Topics include spin and two-level systems,  quantum systems of multiple particles, quantum  description of fermions and bosons, time  independent perturbation theory, and the fine  structure of hydrogen.
PHYS*4040.Requisites:
PHYS*3230
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PHYS*4070.Title: PHYS*4070 Physics in Medicine (0.5 Credits)
PHYS*4070.Description: This course provides an overview of the  application of physics to medicine. The physical  concepts underlying the diagnosis and treatment  of disease will be explored. Topics will include  general imaging principles such as resolution,  intensity, and contrast; x-ray imaging and  computed tomography; radioisotopes and nuclear  medicine, SPECT and PET; magnetic resonance  imaging; ultrasound imaging and radiation  therapy.
PHYS*4070.Requisites:
ENGG*3390 or PHYS*3130
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PHYS*4130.Title: PHYS*4130 Subatomic Physics (0.5 Credits)
PHYS*4130.Description: This course surveys the field of subatomic  physics from radioactive emanations to  conjectured subunits of nucleons. Topics include  quark models; strong, electromagnetic and weak  interactions; isospin, strangeness, conservation  laws and symmetry principles; systematics of  nuclear properties, nuclear radioactivity,  nuclear models and reactions.
PHYS*4130.Requisites:
PHYS*4040
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PHYS*4150.Title: PHYS*4150 Solid State Physics (0.5 Credits)
PHYS*4150.Description: The topics covered in this course include:  bonding in solids, thermal and electrical  properties of solids, energy bands, imperfections  in solids, properties of semiconductors and  insulators.
PHYS*4150.Requisites:
PHYS*4040, PHYS*4240
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PHYS*4500.Title: PHYS*4500 Advanced Physics Laboratory (0.5 Credits)
PHYS*4500.Description: This is a modular course for students in any  physics-related major in which techniques of  nuclear, solid state and molecular physics will  be studied.
PHYS*4500.Restriction: This is a Priority  Access Course. Enrolment may be restricted to  particular programs, specializations or semester  levels during certain periods. Please see the  departmental website for more  information.
PHYS*4500.Requisites:
PHYS*3510
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PHYS*4540.Title: PHYS*4540 Molecular Biophysics (0.5 Credits)
PHYS*4540.Description: Physical methods of determining macromolecular  structure: energetics, intramolecular and  intermolecular forces, with applications to  lamellar structures, information storage, DNA and  RNA, recognition and rejection of foreign  molecules.
PHYS*4540.Requisites:
0.50 credits in biochemistry, (CHEM*3860 or PHYS*3230)
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*1150.Title: POLS*1150 Understanding Politics (0.5 Credits)
POLS*1150.Description: This is the recommended introductory course for  students intending to pursue a specialization in  Political Science. An introduction to the basic  concepts of politics, such as liberty, equality,  social justice, constitutionalism, sovereignty,  federalism, parliamentary versus presidential  government. The course will emphasize the meaning  and use of these terms within Canada in the  context of other political systems.

POLS*1500.Title: POLS*1500 World Politics (0.5 Credits)
POLS*1500.Description: An examination of the fundamental patterns of  international politics, focusing especially on  the major issues and contemporary events at the  root of international conflict. As well, the  reality of globalization and interdependence is  assessed in terms of the alternative patterns of  international cooperation in the contemporary  world.
POLS*1500.Offering: Also offered through  Distance Education format.

POLS*2000.Title: POLS*2000 Political Theory (0.5 Credits)
POLS*2000.Description: A study of the philosophic and ideological  developments which have led to the emergence of  the modern state and contemporary politics.
POLS*2000.Offering: Also offered through Distance Education format.

POLS*2100.Title: POLS*2100 Comparative Politics (0.5 Credits)
POLS*2100.Description: The course provides an introduction to key concepts used in comparative political analysis.
POLS*2100.Requisites: 2.00 credits   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*2150.Title: POLS*2150 Gender and Politics (0.5 Credits)
POLS*2150.Description: This course introduces students to competing  approaches to gender and politics. Students will  examine the interrelationship of gender, politics  and the state, focusing on its implications for  political mobilization, representation and  participation, public policy, global gender  issues in international relations, and cultural  and regional differences in gender politics. The  course provides the student with the conceptual  and analytical tools for upper-year courses on  politics in general and on gender, sexuality and  politics in particular.

POLS*2230.Title: POLS*2230 Public Policy (0.5 Credits)
POLS*2230.Description: The course introduces students to public policy,  including the differences between applied and  explanatory policy analyses, within the larger  context of politics and government. Case studies  of different policy areas are used to illustrate  the challenges of developing, implementing, and  explaining policy in various (and often  interrelated) contexts from the local to the  global.
POLS*2230.Offering: Also offered through  Distance Education format.
POLS*2230.Requisites:
2.00 credits
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*2250.Title: POLS*2250 Public Admin & Governance (0.5 Credits)
POLS*2250.Description: The course explores, from both practical and  theoretical perspectives, planning and  implementation of programs and services through  government departments and agencies and  "alternative" processes and structures, sometimes  involving non-governmental actors. The course  critically evaluates the changing role of  bureaucracy; financial and human resource  management; and the evolving concepts of  responsibility and accountability.
POLS*2250.Offering: Also offered through Distance Education  format.
POLS*2250.Requisites:
2.00 credits
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*2300.Title: POLS*2300 Cdn Government & Politics (0.5 Credits)
POLS*2300.Description: This course explores the core institutions of  Canadian government, including parliamentary  government, federalism, the Charter of Rights and  Freedoms and electoral systems. How these  institutions shape and are shaped by political  parties and social forces, as well as current  issues like Quebec nationalism, identity politics  and Indigenous governance, are covered.
POLS*2300.Offering: Also offered through Distance  Education format.

POLS*2350.Title: POLS*2350 Law and Politics (0.5 Credits)
POLS*2350.Description: This course will consider law as both the output  of political action and as the structure in which  political action occurs. It will introduce  students to core legal concepts, explore the  impact of law on private and public actors, and  help students develop legal research skills.
POLS*2350.Requisites:
2.00 credits
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*3000.Title: POLS*3000 Politics of Africa (0.5 Credits)
POLS*3000.Description: Africa in the 20th Century has been the scene of  rapid political and economic change. This course  analyzes African politics in the light of  contemporary problems of development and  modernization.
POLS*3000.Requisites:
1 of IDEV*2000, POLS*2080, POLS*2100
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*3130.Title: POLS*3130 Law, Pol & Judicial Process (0.5 Credits)
POLS*3130.Description: This course emphasizes the study of the judicial  system as a branch of government and highlights  the interaction between the judiciary, law, the  political process and public policy. Issues such  as judicial selection and Charter of Rights  decisions by courts will be explored. Comparisons  with the judicial process in other countries will  supplement the focus on the Canadian judicial  process.
POLS*3130.Requisites: 1 of POLS*2250, POLS*2300, POLS*2350   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*3140.Title: POLS*3140 Charter of Rights and Freedoms (0.5 Credits)
POLS*3140.Description: This course examines the legal and political  effects of the Canadian Charter of Rights and  Freedoms. Issues to be examined may include the  Charter's influence on Canadian political culture  and identity, interest groups and social  movements, the power of the courts, and public  policy. Analysis of specific Charter sections and  judicial decisions along with comparisons to  other countries will be used to aid the analysis.
POLS*3140.Requisites:
POLS*2300 or POLS*2350
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*3270.Title: POLS*3270 Local Government in Ontario (0.5 Credits)
POLS*3270.Description: Municipal governments are major spenders of  public funds in Canada, and are also the level of  government closest to the people. In this course,  students will examine the major problems  confronting urban government in Ontario.
POLS*3270.Requisites:
7.50 credits
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*3300.Title: POLS*3300 Governing Criminal Justice (0.5 Credits)
POLS*3300.Description: The course provides an overview of the policy  process and outcomes of the Canadian criminal  justice system. Particular emphasis is placed on  examining, using various public policy and public  management perspectives, the practices and  interactions of governmental agencies within the  system, such as police agencies and boards,  departments of Justice, Solicitor-General,  corrections and parole agencies, courts and the  legal profession.
POLS*3300.Offering: Also offered  through Distance Education  format.
POLS*3300.Restriction: This is a Priority  Access Course. Enrolment may be restricted to  particular programs or specializations or  semester levels during certain periods. Please  see the departmental website for more  information.
POLS*3300.Requisites:
1 of POLS*2350, POLS*2250, POLS*2300
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*3350.Title: POLS*3350 Comparative Law and Courts (0.5 Credits)
POLS*3350.Description: The course compares legal systems and judicial processes (such as judicial selection, decision-making, and accountability) across jurisdictions and explores similarities and differences in legal and judicial systems. The course critically analyzes the implications of these differences, such as in terms of judicial power, access to justice, and the protection of rights.
POLS*3350.Requisites: 1 of IDEV*2400, POLS*2100, POLS*2350   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*3410.Title: POLS*3410 US Politics and Government (0.5 Credits)
POLS*3410.Description: This course involves a treatment of the basic  principles and institutions of national  government and politics in the United States as  well as the making and execution of public policy  at the national and state levels.
POLS*3410.Requisites:
POLS*2100 or POLS*2300
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*3440.Title: POLS*3440 Corrupt. Scandal & Pol. Ethics (0.5 Credits)
POLS*3440.Description: This course will introduce students to the  phenomenon of political corruption and the study  of its incidence. Attention will be paid to  historical examples, contemporary scandals, and  analytical articles, dealing with the nature,  causes and effects, and proposed cures of  political corruption, and the ethical dilemmas  inherent in political life.
POLS*3440.Offering: Also  offered through Distance Education  format.
POLS*3440.Requisites:
5.00 credits
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*3650.Title: POLS*3650 Quantitative Methods (0.5 Credits)
POLS*3650.Description: This course examines quantitative research  methods of data analysis used in political  science. Students learn how to apply basic  descriptive and inferential statistical  procedures to research political problems and  test hypotheses. In lab, students will acquire  the skills to perform data analysis
POLS*3650.Restriction: Registration in Criminal Justice  & Public Policy, Political Science (major,  minor or area of concentration), Justice and Legal Studies or International  Development (major only).
POLS*3650.Requisites:
1 of POLS*2650, POLS*3180, SOAN*2120
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*3850.Title: POLS*3850 Experiential Learning in Polit (0.5 Credits)
POLS*3850.Description: This course allows students to reflect upon their  involvement in some form of politically related  activity, including simulations, volunteer  programs, or internship work with government or  non-government organizations. The student must  find a faculty member from the Department of  Political Science willing to act as a supervisor  for the course. See the Political Science website  for the learning contract and other requirements  that must be completed in advance of registering  for this course.
POLS*3850.Restriction: Approval of the  experience and evaluation criteria by the  Undergraduate Committee of the Department of  Political Science. Instructor consent  required.
POLS*3850.Requisites: 10.00 credits, 2.00 of which must be in Political Science.   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*3890.Title: POLS*3890 Government & Politics of India (0.5 Credits)
POLS*3890.Description: The course is designed to provide a survey of the  history, society, culture, politics, government,  bureaucracy and foreign relations of India.
POLS*3890.Requisites:
1 of POLS*2080, POLS*2100, POLS*2200
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*3960.Title: POLS*3960 Sel Topics in Political Sci (0.5 Credits)
POLS*3960.Description: Readings and research in selected areas of the  discipline not covered by regular course  offerings. Students present a proposal and seek  approval from a member of the department in the  semester previous to enrolment in this course.  The method of course presentation, emphasis, and  evaluation are at the discretion of the  instructor.
POLS*3960.Requisites: 1.50 credits at the 3000 level in Political Science or equivalent   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*4020.Title: POLS*4020 Global Law and Courts (1 Credits)
POLS*4020.Description: The seminar critically investigates topics in comparative, transnational, or international law and judicial processes.
POLS*4020.Restriction: POLS*4040. CJPP and CJPP:C students are restricted to a maximum of 3.00 credits in SOC and POLS 4000-level CJPP restricted electives.
POLS*4020.Requisites: 1 of POLS*3020, POLS*3130, POLS*3350   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*4050.Title: POLS*4050 Adv Topics in Law & Politics (1 Credits)
POLS*4050.Description: This course explores advanced topics in law and  politics depending on the interests of the  instructor. Potential topics include  investigating the law and politics of social  change or analyzing debates about the political  power of courts in Canada or in comparative  perspectives.
POLS*4050.Restriction: POLS*4060. CJPP and CJPP:C students are restricted to a maximum of 3.00 credits in SOC and POLS 4000-level CJPP restricted electives. This is a Priority Access Course. Enrolment may be restricted to particular programs or specializations or semester levels during certain periods. Please see the departmental website for more information.
POLS*4050.Requisites: 1 of POLS*3020, POLS*3130, POLS*3140, POLS*3350   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*4070.Title: POLS*4070 Courts & Parliament (1 Credits)
POLS*4070.Description: The course critically examines the complex  relationship between the judiciary and  representative institutions. By comparing the  treatment of current political controversies  (assisted suicide, prostitution, drug treatment),  students will better appreciate the often-subtle  exchanges between the two institutions and  further enhance their research abilities in  regards to both legal and legislative processes.
POLS*4070.Restriction: This is a Priority Access Course. CJPP and CJPP:C students are restricted to a maximum of 3.00 credits in SOC and POLS 4000-level CJPP restricted electives. Enrolment may be restricted to particular programs or specializations or semester levels during certain periods. Please see the departmental website for more information.
POLS*4070.Requisites:
1 of POLS*2350, POLS*3130, POLS*3300
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*4100.Title: POLS*4100 Women, Justice & Public Policy (1 Credits)
POLS*4100.Description: This course will use gender-based analysis in  examining a series of justice and public policy  issues affecting the lives of women, including  equality rights, pay and employment equity,  domestic violence, sexual assault, family policy,  health care policy, and pornography. How do  current policies that developed out of  neoliberalism influence the lives of women in  different ways than men? How can/should they be  changed to recognize the different life  experiences of women as distinguished from men?  The primary focus of the topics covered in this  course will be Canadian.
POLS*4100.Restriction: POLS*4310. CJPP and CJPP:C students are restricted to a maximum of 3.00 credits in SOC and POLS 4000-level CJPP restricted electives. This is a Priority Access Course. Enrolment may be restricted to particular programs or specializations or semester levels during certain periods. Please see the departmental website for more information.
POLS*4100.Requisites: (2 of POLS*2150, POLS*2230, POLS*2250, POLS*2300, POLS*2350, POLS*3250) and 1.00 credits in the Public Policy, Governance and Law or Canadian Politics stream. Streams are defined under the Political Science Major.   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*4110.Title: POLS*4110 Crim Just Policy & Law (1 Credits)
POLS*4110.Description: The seminar critically investigates topics in criminal justice and public policy.
POLS*4110.Restriction: POLS*4130. CJPP and CJPP:C students are restricted to a maximum of 3.00 credits in SOC and POLS 4000-level CJPP restricted electives.
POLS*4110.Requisites: 12.50 credits including POLS*3300   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*4130.Title: POLS*4130 Adv Lec Crim Just Policy & Law (0.5 Credits)
POLS*4130.Description: The course critically investigates topics in criminal justice and public policy.
POLS*4130.Restriction: POLS*4110. CJPP and CJPP:C students are restricted to a maximum of 3.00 credits in SOC and POLS 4000-level CJPP restricted electives.
POLS*4130.Requisites: 12.50 credits including POLS*3300   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*4160.Title: POLS*4160 Multi-level Governance/Canada (1 Credits)
POLS*4160.Description: This course considers the evolving relationship  among levels of government in Canada. The growth  of cities, the growth of policy responsibilities  of provinces, the influence of international  organizations, and the development of First  Nations government in Canada all challenge the  conventional study of federal-provincial  relations in Canada. From year to year, this  course examines one or several of these  contemporary dynamics.
POLS*4160.Restriction: CJPP and CJPP:C students are restricted to a maximum of 3.00 credits in SOC and POLS 4000-level CJPP restricted electives. This is a Priority Access Course. Enrolment may be restricted to particular programs or specializations or semester levels during certain periods. Please see the departmental website for more information.
POLS*4160.Requisites: POLS*2300 and 1.00 credits at the 3000 level in the  Canadian Politics stream. Streams are defined under the Political Science Major.   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*4170.Title: POLS*4170 Global Environmental Politics (1 Credits)
POLS*4170.Description: This seminar critically explores the politics of global environmental governance including the role of state and non-state actors.
POLS*4170.Requisites: 12.50 credits including POLS*3370   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*4200.Title: POLS*4200 Intn'l Political Economy (1 Credits)
POLS*4200.Description: The course relies on theoretical approaches in  IPE to examine relationships between politics and  economics across national and regional levels.  The evolution of the global political economy and  its governance structures is explored, as well as  contemporary debates about globalization and  state and non-state actors' responses.  Issue-areas may include: money and power,  technology, trade, development and the  environment.
POLS*4200.Restriction: This is a Priority  Access Course. Enrolment may be restricted to  particular programs or specializations or  semester levels during certain periods. Please  see the departmental website for more  information.
POLS*4200.Requisites: (1 of POLS*2080, POLS*2100, POLS*2200); and at least 1.00  credits at the 3000 level in the International Relations  and Global Studies stream. Streams are defined under the Political Science Major.   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*4280.Title: POLS*4280 Adv. Lect Public Policy (0.5 Credits)
POLS*4280.Description: The advanced lecture course will examine various  public policy issues, such as social policy,  health care policy, evnironmental policy, or  economic policy in a Canadian or comparative  context.
POLS*4280.Restriction: POLS*4260. CJPP and CJPP:C students are restricted to a maximum of 3.00 credits in SOC and POLS 4000-level CJPP restricted electives. This is a Priority Access Course. Enrolment may be restricted to particular programs or specializations or semester levels during certain periods. Please see the departmental website for more information.
POLS*4280.Requisites: (2 of POLS*2230, POLS*2250, POLS*2300), 1.00 credits in the Public Policy, Governance and Law stream or the Canadian Politics stream. Streams are defined under the Political Science Major.   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*4340.Title: POLS*4340 Nationalism (1 Credits)
POLS*4340.Description: The course examines the role of nationalism in  contemporary politics. Nationalism as such is  understood as a major political force in  state-building. Its impact on both global and  national politics is assessed in relation to  other forms of identity-based politics.
POLS*4340.Requisites: (1 of POLS*2000, POLS*2100, POLS*2200), 0.50 credits at  the 3000 level in the Comparative Politics stream or 0.50  credits at the 3000 level in the International Relations  and Global Studies stream. Streams are defined under the Political Science Major.   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*4730.Title: POLS*4730 Int Relations of Middle East (1 Credits)
POLS*4730.Description: This course is designed as an advanced  introduction to the international relations of  the Middle East. The course focuses on theories  of international relations and their  applicability to specific case studies of Middle  Eastern politics. The course provides a critical  examination of conflicts in the region, and  contextualizes those conflicts within both  realist and neo-realist theories of international  relations. The course also provides a critical  examination of the Arab-Israeli crisis, with a  focus on peace negotiations. The course is  offered as a seminar, with a heavy emphasis on  class participation. Students participate in a  simulation of an Arab-Israeli peace negotiation.
POLS*4730.Requisites: POLS*2200 and 1.00 credit at the 3000 level in the  Comparative Politics and/or International Relations and  Global Studies streams. Streams are defined under the Political Science Major.   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*4900.Title: POLS*4900 Seminar in Political Science (1 Credits)
POLS*4900.Description: This seminar-based course explores a current  issue in Political Science. Topics will vary from  year to year and will reflect the research and  teaching interests of the faculty member  directing the course. Information on the topic of  the current offering can be found on the  departmental website.
POLS*4900.Requisites:
14.00 credits, including 1.00 credits in Political Science  at the 3000 level.
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*4910.Title: POLS*4910 Sel Topics in Political Sci (0.5 Credits)
POLS*4910.Description: This course provides for independent reading and  research in selected areas of the discipline not  covered by regular course offerings. Prior to  enrollment in the course, approval must be  obtained from a member of the department willing  to supervise the research. Students should  approach potential supervisors with a proposal  for readings and research, which may include  reflection and expansion on a subject matter  addressed in previous course assignments.
POLS*4910.Requisites:
1.50 credits at the 3000 level in Political Science or  equivalent
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*4930.Title: POLS*4930 Selected Topics in Poli Sci (1 Credits)
POLS*4930.Description: This course provides for independent reading and  research in selected areas of the discipline not  covered by regular course offerings. Prior to  enrollment in the course, approval must be  obtained from a member of the department willing  to supervise the research. Students should  approach potential supervisors with a proposal  for readings and research, which may include  reflection and expansion on a subject matter  addressed in previous course assignments.
POLS*4930.Requisites:
1.50 credits at the 3000 level in Political Science or  equivalent
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*4970.Title: POLS*4970 Hons. Poli. Sci. Research I (0.5 Credits)
POLS*4970.Description: This is Part I of the Honours Essay. Students  complete the necessary reading and research for  their Honours Essay under the supervision of a  department advisor. A research proposal is  expected by the end of the semester. Political  science majors who wish to pursue an honours  thesis must register in this course in their 7th  semester. Student selection of an approved  subject area and instructor must be completed in  the semester previous to enrolment in this  course.
POLS*4970.Restriction: Instructor consent required. CJPP and CJPP:C students are restricted to a maximum of 3.00 credits in SOC and POLS 4000-level CJPP restricted electives.
POLS*4970.Requisites:
70% average in all POLS courses. Recommendation: Students  with less than a 75% average are advised not to take this  course.
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POLS*4980.Title: POLS*4980 Hons. Poli. Sci. Research II (0.5 Credits)
POLS*4980.Description: This is Part II of the Honours Essay. Students  organize and write their essays under the  supervision of their advisor. Major honours  political science students must register in this  course in their 8th semester.
POLS*4980.Restriction: Instructor consent required. CJPP and CJPP:C students are restricted to a maximum of 3.00 credits in SOC and POLS 4000-level CJPP restricted electives.
POLS*4980.Requisites:
POLS*4970
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

POPM*3240.Title: POPM*3240 Epidemiology (0.5 Credits)
POPM*3240.Description: The course examines the basic concepts of health  and disease in populations. Methods used in  descriptive and analytic epidemiological studies,  including the design, analysis and interpretation  of results for observational studies and field  trials are presented.
POPM*3240.Offering: Also offered  through Distance Education  format.
POPM*3240.Restriction: This is a Priority  Access Course. Some restrictions may apply during  some time periods. Please see the Department of  Population Medicine website for more  information.
POPM*3240.Requisites: (BIOL*1080 or BIOL*1090), (1 of SOAN*2120, STAT*2040, STAT*2230)   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*1000.Title: PSYC*1000 Introduction to Psychology (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*1000.Description: This is an introduction to the content and  methods of psychology. It will cover the major  areas such as neuroscience, sensation and  perception, learning, cognition, motivation,  human development, personality, psychopathology  and its treatment, and social psychology.
PSYC*1000.Offering: Also offered through Distance  Education format.
PSYC*1000.Restriction: This is a Priority Access Course. Enrolment may be restricted to particular programs or semester levels during certain periods.
PSYC*1000.Offered: Summer, Fall, and Winter, All Years

PSYC*1010.Title: PSYC*1010 Making Sense of Data (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*1010.Description: This course introduces research designs and  quantitative approaches used in psychological  science, with an emphasis on conceptual  understanding. Specific topics include  distributions, meta-analysis, confidence  intervals and p-values, effect size, and  regression, as well as the differences between  descriptive, correlational, and experimental  research designs.
PSYC*1010.Restriction: STAT*2040, STAT*2060, STAT*2080, STAT*2120, STAT*2230. This is a Priority Access Course. Enrolment may be restricted to particular programs or semester levels during certain periods.
PSYC*1010.Requisites:
PSYC*1000
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*1500.Title: PSYC*1500 Foundational Skills in Psych (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*1500.Description: This course is designed to help Psychology majors  to optimize their learning in the Psychology  program. The primary focus is on individual skill  development with respect to academic learning,  written and oral communication, career planning,  and working in groups. Specific topics will vary  by instructor.
PSYC*1500.Requisites: PSYC*1000   - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

PSYC*2020.Title: PSYC*2020 Clinical Psyc & Mental Health (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*2020.Description: This course is an introduction to clinical psychology and mental health including a multidimensional conceptualization of mental health, assessment, diagnosis, and treatment. Common psychological disorders will be explored with respect to etiology, assessment, current diagnosis and classification, as well as treatment. Emphasis will be given to broad empirical research and to the experiences of individuals with these disorders.
PSYC*2020.Offering: Also offered through Distance Education format.
PSYC*2020.Restriction: This is a Priority Access Course. Enrolment may be restricted to particular programs or semester levels during certain periods.
PSYC*2020.Requisites:
PSYC*1000
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*2070.Title: PSYC*2070 Teams Leadership & Prof Beh (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*2070.Description: The course will focus on the theory and practical  application of Organizational Psychology with  regard to leadership, teams, and professional  behaviour. The course will provide students with  opportunities to assess their leadership and  teamwork skills, as well as active learning  activities to practice these skills. Key topics  will include work motivation, time management,  personal organizational skills, goal setting,  conflict management, social influence and stress  management.
PSYC*2070.Requisites:
PSYC*1500 or 4.00 credits in Psychology
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*2310.Title: PSYC*2310 Social Psychology (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*2310.Description: This course introduces students to the field of  social psychology. Major topics introduced will  include: social influence, social cognition,  attitude, stereotype and prejudice, the self,  attraction and interpersonal relationships, group  processes and intergroup relations. The course  also aims for students to use the knowledge  acquired to think critically about how their  actions and those of others are influenced by  social forces. In addition, the course aims to  introduce students to the role of culture in  shaping thoughts and behaviour and to provide  them an opportunity to appreciate diverse  perspectives.
PSYC*2310.Offering: Also offered through  Distance Education format.
PSYC*2310.Restriction: This is a Priority Access Course. Enrolment may be restricted to particular programs or semester levels during certain periods.
PSYC*2310.Requisites: PSYC*1000   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*2330.Title: PSYC*2330 Principles of Learning (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*2330.Description: This course provides a detailed description of  principles and concepts of learning and  motivation, as well as an introduction to their  underlying neurobiological mechanisms. Through  the examination of empirical evidence in the  fields of Psychology and Behavioural  Neuroscience, this course offers a comprehensive  description of the role of conditioning in normal  and abnormal behaviours.
PSYC*2330.Offering: Also offered through Distance Education format.
PSYC*2330.Restriction: This is a Priority Access Course. Enrolment may be restricted to particular programs or semester levels during certain periods.
PSYC*2330.Requisites:
PSYC*1000
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*2360.Title: PSYC*2360 Psych Methods & Statistics (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*2360.Description: This course builds on students' understanding of  basic psychological research methods and  statistics, with an emphasis on designing,  interpreting, and communicating research. Topics  covered throughout the term may include: research  ethics, the scientific method, qualitative and  quantitative measures, reliability and validity,  complex research designs using multiple predictor  or independent variables, and the reading and  writing of psychological journal articles.
PSYC*2360.Requisites: PSYC*1000, (1 of PSYC*1010, STAT*2040, STAT*2060, STAT*2080, STAT*2120, STAT*2230)   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*2390.Title: PSYC*2390 Sensation and Perception (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*2390.Description: The course objective is to consider the processes  of sensory inputs and perception. Approaches  ranging from psychophysiology and cognitive  psychology to physiology and anatomy will be  used. In considering the psychology of sensation  and perception, some of the anatomical and  physiological aspects of selected senses will be  covered in detail and the roles of experience,  organization of inputs, and theories of  perception are discussed. Topics to be emphasized  will vary with the instructor, but may include  ontogenetic development, learning, and  modification of inputs and their perception.  Students will participate in on-line laboratory  demonstrations and experiments.
PSYC*2390.Offering: Also offered through Distance Education  format.
PSYC*2390.Restriction: This is a Priority Access Course. Enrolment may be restricted to particular programs or semester levels during certain periods.
PSYC*2390.Requisites: PSYC*1000   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*2450.Title: PSYC*2450 Developmental Psychology (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*2450.Description: This course is an introduction to and an analysis  of the major theories of developmental  psychology. Emphasis will be placed on the  processes of development in the child including  physical growth, perception, cognition,  personality and interactions with the social  environment. The application of developmental  psychology to educational and social issues will  be discussed.
PSYC*2450.Offering: Also offered through  Distance Education format.
PSYC*2450.Restriction: FRHD*2270. This is a Priority Access Course. Enrolment may be restricted to particular programs or semester levels during certain periods.
PSYC*2450.Requisites: PSYC*1000   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*2650.Title: PSYC*2650 Cognitive Psychology (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*2650.Description: This course is an introduction to cognitive  processes, including topics in the areas of  attention, memory, language and reasoning.  Students will be exposed to and participate in  on-line laboratory demonstrations and  experiments.
PSYC*2650.Offering: Also offered through  Distance Education format.
PSYC*2650.Restriction: This  is a Priority Access Course. Enrolment may be restricted to particular programs or semester levels during certain periods.
PSYC*2650.Requisites: PSYC*1000   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*2740.Title: PSYC*2740 Personality (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*2740.Description: This course is a review of the theory, assessment  procedures and research findings pertinent to  major personality constructs. Personality  research, methodology and design will also be  covered.
PSYC*2740.Offering: Also offered through  Distance Education format.
PSYC*2740.Restriction: This  is a Priority Access Course. Enrolment may be restricted to particular programs or semester levels during certain periods.
PSYC*2740.Requisites: PSYC*1000   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*3000.Title: PSYC*3000 Historical & Crit Persp on Psy (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*3000.Description: The purpose of this course is to help students  understand the socio-historical and theoretical  context of modern psychological research and  practice. This includes: 1) evaluating basic  assumptions underlying modern psychology by  drawing on historical, theoretical and  philosophical perspectives, and 2) investigating  historical and current controversies within  psychology. Topics may include the question of  psychology's scientific status, the assumptions  embedded in psychological theory and research  methodology, social constructionism, free  will/agency, and the relations between  psychology, power, ethics, and politics.
PSYC*3000.Requisites: PSYC*2070, PSYC*2360, (3 of PSYC*2020, PSYC*2310, PSYC*2330, PSYC*2390, PSYC*2410, PSYC*2450, PSYC*2650, PSYC*2740)   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*3020.Title: PSYC*3020 Psychology of Law (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*3020.Description: An examination of psychological methods, findings  and theories in the study of law. Topics will  include the fallibility of the eyewitness; juror  decisional processes; credibility of witnesses  and attorneys; socialization into legal systems,  police behaviour, etc.
PSYC*3020.Offering: Also offered  through Distance Education  format.
PSYC*3020.Requisites:
2.50 credits in Psychology or PSYC*2310
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*3030.Title: PSYC*3030 Neurochem Basis of Behaviour (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*3030.Description: This course analyses how drugs act on various  neurochemical systems to regulate motivation and  behaviour. Topics of discussion may include  psychopathology and its treatment.
PSYC*3030.Requisites:
2.00 credits in Psychology, (1 of BIOM*3090, NEUR*2000,  PSYC*2410)
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*3240.Title: PSYC*3240 Independent Research (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*3240.Description: This course provides individual students with  hands-on experience conducting a research  project. Students are supervised directly by a  faculty member as they conduct an in-depth  investigation of a specific topic within  psychology. Typically, the course involves both  the practice and reporting of research. Through  this experience students will develop a broader  appreciation of the relations between knowledge,  theory and research while acquiring basic skills  in research methodologies and modes of inquiry.  In addition, students will develop their written  and oral communication skills (e.g., integration  of relevant literature, reporting of research).  Course registration requires the signature of the  Psychology Academic Manager. This signature is  contingent upon the student demonstrating they  have obtained a faculty supervisor's signature  and satisfy the course prerequisites. Please see  the Psychology department website for more  information. https://www.uoguelph.ca/psychology/
PSYC*3240.Restriction: A minimum 75% cumulative average in Psychology courses. Instructor consent required.
PSYC*3240.Requisites:
2.50 credits in Psychology including PSYC*2360
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*3290.Title: PSYC*3290 Statistical Analysis in Psych (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*3290.Description: This course focuses on training students in the  quantitative analysis and communications skills  needed to become a researcher in psychology.  Students conduct a correlation-based  meta-analysis to help them concretely understand  sampling distributions and the difficulties  associated with obtaining study results that  replicate. This meta-analytic foundation is then  leveraged to teach traditional psychological  analysis techniques (e.g., t-test, analysis of  variance, and bi-variate/multiple regression)  with an emphasis on maximizing factors that  increase the probability of study findings that  replicate. The value of interpreting results  using effect sizes with confidence intervals is  discussed and the logic of null-hypothesis  testing is briefly reviewed.
PSYC*3290.Restriction: STAT*2050, STAT*2090. Restricted to students in BAH.PSYC, BAH.PSYC:C, BSCH.NEUR, BSCH.NEUR:C with a minimum 70% cumulative average in Psychology courses.
PSYC*3290.Requisites:
2.50 credits in Psychology including PSYC*2360
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*3300.Title: PSYC*3300 Psychology of Gender (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*3300.Description: This course will examine the theories and  psychological research that deals with the impact  of gender upon people's lives and behaviour.  Topics will include gender-role socialization and  stereotypes; gender-related status and power  differentials; and gender differences and  dynamics in the physiological, intrapsychic,  interpersonal, and socio-cultural domains.
PSYC*3300.Requisites:
2.50 credits in Psychology including PSYC*2310
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*3410.Title: PSYC*3410 Behavioural Neuroscience II (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*3410.Description: This course will focus on contemporary research  and theory related to such selected topics as  physiological correlates of memory, learning,  motivation, emotion, stress, sensory and motor  functions. Both the central and peripheral  components of the nervous system will be examined  in relation to the above.
PSYC*3410.Restriction: Restricted to students in Neuroscience (major or  Minor). This is a Priority Access Course. Some  restrictions may apply during some time  periods.
PSYC*3410.Requisites:
NEUR*2000 or PSYC*2410
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*3470.Title: PSYC*3470 Putting Psychology to Work (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*3470.Description: This course provides students with the  opportunity to prepare for the transition to  post-graduate programs and work, by exploring  psychology as it relates to work. Topics include:  the history of work and industrial psychology,  career management, job analysis, recruitment,  selection, employment law, compensation and  benefits, performance appraisal, training and  development, as well as succession planning.
PSYC*3470.Offering: Also offered through Distance Education format.
PSYC*3470.Restriction: Restricted to BAH.PSYC, BAH.PSYC:C, and BAG.PSYC. This is a Priority Access Course. Enrolment may be restricted to particular programs or semester levels during certain periods.
PSYC*3470.Requisites:
PSYC*2070, PSYC*2360, (2 of PSYC*2020, PSYC*2310,  PSYC*2450, PSYC*2740), (1 of PSYC*2330, PSYC*2390,  PSYC*2410, PSYC*2650)
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*3480.Title: PSYC*3480 Psychology of Sport (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*3480.Description: This course provides an examination of individual  and group behaviour in physical activities and  sports. Emphasis will be placed on understanding  psychological concepts which are pertinent to  sports, e.g., motivation, social and personality  development, cognition, leadership and group  dynamics.
PSYC*3480.Offering: Offered through Distance  Education format only.
PSYC*3480.Requisites: PSYC*1000 and 4.50 credits   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*3570.Title: PSYC*3570 Psychology of Death & Dying (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*3570.Description: An examination of theory, research, and issues in  the psychology of death and dying. Emphasis is  upon the cognitive operations used to process  information about death and the influence of  death constructs in daily life. Topics include  the development of death concepts throughout the  life-span, death anxiety in society, the needs of  the dying person, the psychology of grieving, and  unexpected losses such as deaths by suicide or  miscarriage.
PSYC*3570.Offering: Offered through  Distance Education format only.
PSYC*3570.Requisites: PSYC*1000 and 4.50 credits   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*3910.Title: PSYC*3910 Psychology Externship (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*3910.Description: An independent program of study formally integrating the student's academic study with one or more work experiences, to be decided by the student in consultation with the supervisory faculty prior to registration in the course. In order to qualify for this course, the student must be employed in a work setting at the time of registration to help ensure that a suitable project is feasible in the context of a work placement or employment. The department is not responsible for obtaining employment. The course project is aimed at making a significant contribution to the work setting. The student must consult with the supervisory faculty before selecting or registering for the course. (Enrolment is limited. Not open to co-op students.)
PSYC*3910.Restriction: Restricted to BAH.PSYC and BAG.PSYC. Not available to students in BAH.PSYC:C. Instructor consent required.
PSYC*3910.Requisites:
PSYC*2070, PSYC*2360, (2 of PSYC*2020, PSYC*2310,  PSYC*2450, PSYC*2740), (1 of PSYC*2330, PSYC*2390,  PSYC*2410, PSYC*2650)
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*4240.Title: PSYC*4240 Adv Independent Research (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*4240.Description: This course provides individual students with  hands-on experience conducting a research  project. Students are supervised directly by a  faculty member as they conduct an in-depth  investigation of a specific topic within  psychology. Typically, the course involves both  the practice and reporting of research. Students  will apply the research and communication skills  they have acquired through prior coursework in  order to work more independently. Course  registration requires the signature of the  Psychology Academic Manager. This signature is  contingent upon the student demonstrating they  have obtained a faculty supervisor's signature  and satisfy the course prerequisites. Please see  the Psychology department website for more  information. https://www.uoguelph.ca/psychology/
PSYC*4240.Restriction: Restricted to students in BAH.PSYC, BAH.PSYC:C, BSCH.NEUR, or BSCH.NEUR:C with a minimum 75% cumulative average in Psychology courses. Instructor consent required.
PSYC*4240.Requisites: 14.00 credits including (PSYC*3290, 1.00 credits in Psychology at the 3000 level)   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*4290.Title: PSYC*4290 Psychological Measurement (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*4290.Description: This course focuses on training students how to conduct research such that measurement theory guides measure selection and construction. Consequences of measurement theory (reliability/validity) for the accuracy of research findings and interpretation of test scores are also covered. A variety of individual difference variables are examined with an emphasis on how measurement strategies differ depending on the nature of the construct.
PSYC*4290.Restriction: PSYC*3250. Restricted to students in BAH.PSYC, BAH.PSYC:C, BSCH.NEUR, BSCH.NEUR:C or minor in Neuroscience with a minimum 70% cumulative average in Psychology courses.
PSYC*4290.Requisites: PSYC*3290   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*4310.Title: PSYC*4310 Adv Social/Applied Social Psyc (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*4310.Description: This is an in-depth examination of specific  advances in social psychological research,  theory, and/or applications. Selected topic areas  may include the psychology of social groups,  women's health and well-being, and community  interventions. Specific topics, to be announced  prior to course selection, will vary according to  the interests of the instructor of the course.
PSYC*4310.Restriction: Restricted to students in BAH.PSYC or BAH.PSYC:C with a minimum 70% cumulative average in Psychology courses.
PSYC*4310.Requisites: 14.00 credits including PSYC*2310, PSYC*3290   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*4330.Title: PSYC*4330 Adv Topics in I/O Psychology (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*4330.Description: Students will examine theoretical and  methodological issues in selected topic areas of  industrial/organizational psychology. Selected  topic areas may include diversity issues, trust  and justice, job performance, employment  selection, and stress and well-being. Specific  topics, to be announced prior to course  selection, will vary according to the interests  of the instructor of the course.
PSYC*4330.Restriction: Restricted to students in BAH.PSYC or BAH.PSYC:C with a minimum 70% cumulative average in Psychology courses.
PSYC*4330.Requisites: 14.00 credits including PSYC*3290, (1 of PSYC*2070, PSYC*3490)   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*4460.Title: PSYC*4460 Adv Top in Clin & App Dvt Psyc (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*4460.Description: This course covers issues and theories in  clinical or applied developmental psychology.  Topics may include pediatric (child health)  psychology, attachment relationships,  non-suicidal self-injury, and aggression. The  selected topic, to be announced prior to course  selection, will vary on the basis of the  expertise of the instructor.
PSYC*4460.Restriction: Restricted to students in BAH.PSYC or BAH.PSYC:C with a minimum 70% cumulative average in Psychology courses.
PSYC*4460.Requisites: 14.00 credits including PSYC*2020, PSYC*3290, (1 of FRHD*2270, PSYC*2450, PSYC*2740)   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*4540.Title: PSYC*4540 Practical Applications of Psyc (1 Credits)
PSYC*4540.Description: This is a required capstone course for students  in Psychology's BA and BSC Honours major  programs, excepting those who are taking the  Honours Thesis courses (PSYC*4780, 4880). The  course adopts a problem-based learning approach  in which students will be presented with problems  resembling those that they will face in their  professional and personal lives. Students will  apply their psychological knowledge and skills to  analyze the problem, consider solutions, and  communicate recommendations to hypothetical  stakeholders.
PSYC*4540.Restriction: PSYC*4870, PSYC*4880. Restricted to students in BAH.PSYC or BAH.PSYC:C with a minimum 70% cumulative average in Psychology courses.
PSYC*4540.Requisites: 14.00 credits including PSYC*3290, (PSYC*3000 or 7.50 credits in Psychology)   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.
PSYC*4540.Locations: 14.00 credits including PSYC*3290, (PSYC*3000 or 7.50 credits in Psychology)   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*4580.Title: PSYC*4580 Spec Topics in Behav Sciences (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*4580.Description: This course provides an in-depth examination of  specific theoretical and methodological advances  for understanding human and/or animal behaviour.  Specific topics will vary according to the  expertise of the instructor, but could include  advances in Social Psychology,  Industrial/Organizational Psychology, Cognitive  or Behavioural Neuroscience.
PSYC*4580.Restriction: Restricted to students in BAH.PSYC, BAH.PSYC:C, BSCH.NEUR, or BSCH.NEUR:C with a minimum 70% cumulative average in Psychology courses.
PSYC*4580.Requisites: 14.00 credits including PSYC*3290, 1.00 credits in Psychology at the 3000 level   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*4750.Title: PSYC*4750 Motivation & Emotion (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*4750.Description: This course provides an in-depth examination of motivation and emotion- the neurocognitive mechanisms and corresponding subjective feelings that focus thoughts and behaviours in an adaptive way toward some objects and events in the environment and away from others. The course material and assignments will cover what is known about motivation and emotion from research in the fields of biological, cognitive, and/or social psychology, emotion theory, and cognitive-affective neuroscience.
PSYC*4750.Restriction: Restricted to students in BAH.PSYC, BAH.PSYC:C, BSCH.NEUR, BSCH.NEUR:C, or MIN.NEUR with a minimum 70% cumulative average in Psychology courses.
PSYC*4750.Requisites:
14.00 credits including 1.50 credits in Psychology at the  3000 level
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*4870.Title: PSYC*4870 Honours Thesis I (0.5 Credits)
PSYC*4870.Description: Under individual faculty supervision, students  plan, develop, and write a research proposal and  prepare an extensive review paper on their area  of research. Group sessions are held on research  ethics, subject protocols and computer data  handling techniques. This course will be graded  on a Pass/Fail basis. Note that enrolment in this  course is limited and academic records are used  for student selection. Course registration  requires the signature of the Course Instructor.  This signature is contingent upon the student  demonstrating they have obtained a Thesis  Supervisor's signature on the department's Thesis  Registration Form and have an academic standing  appropriate for application to graduate programs  (see Graduate Advisory under Major).
PSYC*4870.Restriction: PSYC*4540. Restricted to students in BAH.PSYC, BAH.PSYC:C, BSCH.NEUR or BSCH.NEUR:C with a minimum 75% cumulative average in Psychology courses. Instructor consent required.
PSYC*4870.Requisites:
14.00 credits including (1 of NEUR*3500, PSYC*3000, 7.50  credits in Psychology)
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.
PSYC*4870.Offered: 1 of NEUR*4000, PSYC*4780, PSYC*4790   - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.
PSYC*4870.Locations:
14.00 credits including (1 of NEUR*3500, PSYC*3000, 7.50  credits in Psychology)
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

PSYC*4880.Title: PSYC*4880 Honours Thesis II (1 Credits)
PSYC*4880.Description: This course is a continuation of PSYC*4870.  Students conduct research and write an  undergraduate thesis under the direction of a  faculty member.
PSYC*4880.Restriction: PSYC*4540. Restricted to students in BAH.PSYC, BAH.PSYC:C, BSCH.NEUR or BSCH.NEUR:C with a minimum 75% cumulative average in Psychology courses. Instructor consent required.
PSYC*4880.Requisites:
PSYC*4870
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

REAL*1820.Title: REAL*1820 Introduction to Real Estate (0.5 Credits)
REAL*1820.Description: This survey course acquaints students with the theories, practices and principles of real estate and housing. Topics include how real estate assets and markets differ from other assets: including real estate economics, financing, development, appraisal, brokerage, zoning, property management, taxation, and government involvement. Many property types may be considered, including residential, multi-residential, office, industrial, and retail.
REAL*1820.Restriction: This is a Priority Access  Course. Some restrictions may apply during some  time periods. Please contact the department for  more information.
REAL*1820.Department: Department of  Marketing and Consumer Studies

REAL*2820.Title: REAL*2820 Real Estate Finance (0.5 Credits)
REAL*2820.Description: This course examines the financing of both  residential and commercial investment real  estate. A mathematical approach is used to  examine the impact of various lender and borrower  decisions about loan terms (amortization periods,  pre-payment options, etc.). The evolution of the  Canadian housing finance system is contrasted  with that in the United States. New methods of  financing real estate other than traditional  mortgages are discussed.
REAL*2820.Restriction: This is  a Priority Access Course. Some restrictions may  apply during some time periods. Please contact  the department for more  information.
REAL*2820.Department: Department of  Marketing and Consumer Studies
REAL*2820.Requisites:
5.00 credits
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

REAL*3880.Title: REAL*3880 Topics in Real Estate (0.5 Credits)
REAL*3880.Description: Lecture-discussion or seminar on a selected topic  related to real estate to be conducted by faculty  with special interests or expertise in the area.  Students should confirm with the department prior  to course selection what topic(s), if any, will  be offered during specific semesters.
REAL*3880.Department: Department of Marketing  and Consumer Studies
REAL*3880.Requisites: 10.00 credits including REAL*1820   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

REAL*3890.Title: REAL*3890 Property Management (0.5 Credits)
REAL*3890.Description: This course considers the various strategies  which a well-managed property can use to benefit  tenants, employees and investors. Given the  increasing professionalization of the industry,  the relationship between property management and  asset management is discussed. Issues faced by  managers of residential, office, retail,  industrial and mixed-use properties are covered.
REAL*3890.Restriction: This is a Priority Access  Course. Some restrictions may apply during some  time periods. Please contact the department for  more information.
REAL*3890.Department: Department of  Marketing and Consumer Studies
REAL*3890.Requisites:
REAL*1820, (ACCT*2230 or REAL*2820)
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

REAL*4830.Title: REAL*4830 Real Estate Development Proj (1 Credits)
REAL*4830.Description: This is a capstone course covering the real  estate development process and bringing together  concepts from all other Real Estate and Housing  courses. It deals with the development,  redevelopment and renewal of real estate and  housing services. Students will complete a phased  project that considers all aspects of development  feasibility including market analysis, physical  constraints, financial viability and government  regulation.
REAL*4830.Restriction: This is a Priority  Access Course. Some restrictions may apply during  some time periods. Please contact the department  for more information.
REAL*4830.Department: Department  of Marketing and Consumer Studies
REAL*4830.Requisites:
15.00 credits including REAL*3810, REAL*4820
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

SART*1050.Title: SART*1050 Foundation Studio (0.5 Credits)
SART*1050.Description: This course provides a foundation in the  technical and theoretical aspects of contemporary  two-dimensional media. Through a combination of  lectures, studio projects, readings and a field  trip the students will explore perceptual,  conceptual and topical dimensions of art making  practices.
SART*1050.Restriction: Registration in  semesters one, two, three or four. May not  register in SART*1060 in the same term. This is a  Priority Access Course. Enrolment may be  restricted to particular programs or  specializations during certain periods. Please  see the departmental website for more  information.
SART*1050.Department: School of Fine Art  and Music

SART*1060.Title: SART*1060 Core Studio (0.5 Credits)
SART*1060.Description: This course provides a foundation in the technical and theoretical aspects of contemporary three-dimensional and time-based media. Through a combination of lectures, research assignments and studio projects, students will explore perceptual, conceptual and topical dimensions of contemporary art making practices.
SART*1060.Restriction: Registration in semesters one, two, three or four. May not register in SART*1050 in the same term. This is a Priority Access Course. Enrolment may be restricted to particular programs or specializations during certain periods. Please see the departmental website for more information.
SART*1060.Department: School of Fine Art and Music

SART*2090.Title: SART*2090 Drawing I (0.5 Credits)
SART*2090.Description: This course will consider the activity of drawing  as an ability to work with a varied range of  applications - all of them concerned with the  investigation and development of idea through  making an image. This course is an introduction  to the basic concepts, techniques and media of  drawing, through disciplined observational and  imaginative study.
SART*2090.Restriction: This is a  Priority Access Course. Enrolment may be  restricted to particular programs,  specializations, majors or semester levels during  certain periods. Please see the department for  more information.
SART*2090.Department: School of Fine  Art and Music
SART*2090.Requisites:
(1 of ARTH*1220, ARTH*1510, ARTH*1520), SART*1050,  SART*1060
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.
SART*2090.Locations: SART*1060 can be taken as co-requisite   - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

SART*2200.Title: SART*2200 Painting I (0.5 Credits)
SART*2200.Description: This course is designed to introduce students to  the fundamentals of observational painting in oil  and acrylic paint. In addition to developing  skill in colour-mixing, composition, and using  value to create space and form, students will  learn proper care for tools and how to prepare  supports. Regular discussions of contemporary and  relevant historical examples will assist students  to understand their work as part of the broader  conversation and discourse in painting. Prior or  concurrent Drawing classes are recommended.
SART*2200.Restriction: This is a Priority Access  Course. Enrolment may be restricted to particular  programs, specializations, majors or semester  levels during certain periods. Please see the  department for more information.
SART*2200.Department: School of Fine Art and Music
SART*2200.Requisites:
(1 of ARTH*1220, ARTH*1510, ARTH*1520), SART*1050,  SART*1060
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.
SART*2200.Locations: SART*1060 can be taken as co-requisite   - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

SART*2300.Title: SART*2300 Sculpture I (0.5 Credits)
SART*2300.Description: This course is an introduction to contemporary  sculptural concerns through projects, readings  and visual research. Sculptural principles of  form and space will be addressed through hands-on  engagement with a variety of materials and  methods. Readings provide an overview of  Modernist sculpture and basic critical theory.
SART*2300.Restriction: This is a Priority Access  Course. Enrolment may be restricted to particular  programs, specializations, majors or semester  levels during certain periods. Please see the  department for more information.
SART*2300.Department: School of Fine Art and Music
SART*2300.Requisites:
(1 of ARTH*1220, ARTH*1510, ARTH*1520, ARTH*2220),  SART*1050, SART*1060
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.
SART*2300.Locations: SART*1050 can be taken as co-requisite   - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

SART*2460.Title: SART*2460 Printmaking I (0.5 Credits)
SART*2460.Description: This course is an introduction to the printmaking  media of intaglio, relief and silkscreen.  Conceptual issues will be examined in relation to  the creation of prints with discussions around  the characteristics of the edition, the monoprint  and the series through printmaking objects and  readings.
SART*2460.Restriction: This is a Priority  Access Course. Enrolment may be restricted to  particular programs, specializations, majors or  semester levels during certain periods. Please  see the department for more  information.
SART*2460.Department: School of Fine Art  and Music
SART*2460.Requisites:
(1 of ARTH*1220, ARTH*1510, ARTH*1520), SART*1050,  SART*1060
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.
SART*2460.Locations: SART*1060 can be taken as co-requisite   - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

SART*2610.Title: SART*2610 Photography I (0.5 Credits)
SART*2610.Description: This course is an introduction to the historic,  conceptual, and material nature of photography in  contemporary art. Course content will include  basic digital, analogue and studio techniques,  and an exploration of historic techniques such as  the Photogram and Camera Obscura. Readings,  discussions, and assignments will forge  connections between historic and contemporary  modes of image making, and will encourage  students to experiment with innovative ways of  utilizing the photographic medium.
SART*2610.Restriction: This is a Priority Access  Course. Enrolment may be restricted to particular  programs, specializations, majors or semester  levels during certain periods. Please see the  department for more information.
SART*2610.Department: School of Fine Art and Music
SART*2610.Requisites:
(1 of ARTH*1220, ARTH*1510, ARTH*1520), SART*1050,  SART*1060
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.
SART*2610.Locations: SART*1060 can be taken as co-requisite   - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

SART*2800.Title: SART*2800 Experimental Studio I (0.5 Credits)
SART*2800.Description: This course introduces students to different  processes used by the contemporary studio artist,  with an emphasis on time-based and  interdisciplinary forms of production. Students  will be actively engaged in exploring a variety  of skills, processes and concepts, in the  development of video and audio art, artist  multiples, and site-specific interventions. An  understanding of the technical, theoretical, and  historical concerns of experimental art practices  will provide a solid base for upper level  courses, where students will develop a stronger  capacity to work with media that are appropriate  to realize their ideas.
SART*2800.Restriction: This is  a Priority Access Course. Enrolment may be  restricted to particular programs,  specializations, majors or semester levels during  certain periods. Please see the department for  more information.
SART*2800.Department: School of Fine  Art and Music
SART*2800.Requisites:
(1 of ARTH*1220, ARTH*1510, ARTH*1520, ARTH*2220),  SART*1050, SART*1060
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.
SART*2800.Locations: SART*1050 can be taken as co-requisite   - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

SART*3090.Title: SART*3090 Drawing II (0.5 Credits)
SART*3090.Description: This course attempts to foster understanding of  the basis and technical issues necessary to the  making of drawings while introducing the  philosophical and critical issues related to the  discipline. This course will consider drawing as  an activity with a wide range of applications.
SART*3090.Restriction: Registration is limited to  students registered in the Art History or Studio  Art specializations with an average of 70% in all  ARTH and SART course attempts.
SART*3090.Department: School of Fine Art and Music
SART*3090.Requisites:
SART*2090
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

SART*3200.Title: SART*3200 Painting II (0.5 Credits)
SART*3200.Description: In this course, technical, aesthetic and  philosophical issues central to contemporary  painting will be investigated. These include  diverse approaches to representational painting  today as well as an introduction to abstraction  and other non-representational strategies.  Activities such as class discussions, field trips  and presentations on contemporary artists will  assist students to situate their own developing  practices within the field.
SART*3200.Restriction: Registration is limited to students registered in  the Art History or Studio Art specializations  with an average of 70% in all ARTH and SART  course attempts.
SART*3200.Department: School of Fine  Art and Music
SART*3200.Requisites:
SART*2200
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

SART*3300.Title: SART*3300 Sculpture II (0.5 Credits)
SART*3300.Description: This is a technical and experimental course in which critical issues in post-modernist and contemporary sculpture will be explored and deployed. Projects will focus on skills training in the wood shop, metal shop and technologies for digital fabrication. Readings will provide an overview of post-modernist and contemporary sculpture.
SART*3300.Restriction: Registration is  limited to students registered in the Art History  or Studio Art specializations with an average of  70% in all ARTH and SART course  attempts.
SART*3300.Department: School of Fine Art and  Music
SART*3300.Requisites:
SART*2300
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

SART*3660.Title: SART*3660 Printmaking II (0.5 Credits)
SART*3660.Description: This course provides an introduction to stone  lithography and will continue to investigate the  formal and technical aspects of printmaking  techniques covered in SART*2460. Students will be  actively engaged in exploring contemporary  concerns in printmaking through ideas of  dissemination, sequence and systems through  scrutiny of printmaking objects and readings.
SART*3660.Department: School  of Fine Art and Music
SART*3660.Requisites:
SART*2460
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

SART*3750.Title: SART*3750 Photography II (0.5 Credits)
SART*3750.Description: This course encourages students to develop an experimental, ambitious, and exploratory studio arts practice. Course material is presented through lectures, labs, and critiques to engage with the form, content, and technical attributes of the medium. Students will explore the creative uses of colour and scale. In-class discussions, readings and seminars are designed to provide students with a critical and historical understanding of the art-making process.
SART*3750.Restriction: Registration is limited to students registered in the Art History or Studio Art specializations with an average of 70% in all ARTH and SART course attempts.
SART*3750.Department: School of Fine Art and Music
SART*3750.Requisites:
SART*2610
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

SART*3770.Title: SART*3770 Experimental Studio II (0.5 Credits)
SART*3770.Description: Students will explore and consider the found  object and appropriation in art, the use of  language and text in art, and other conceptual  art practices in various media. In a context of  critical reading, writing, class exercises and  discussion - students will continue developing  their technical skills in video and sound  production. We may also consider such forms as  collage, the artist book and/or artist multiple,  performance, social practice art, and other  experimental studio strategies.
SART*3770.Restriction: Registration is limited to students registered in  the Art History or Studio Art specializations  with an average of 70% in all ARTH and SART  course attempts.
SART*3770.Department: School of Fine  Art and Music
SART*3770.Requisites:
SART*2800
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

SART*3800.Title: SART*3800 Experiential Learning I (0.5 Credits)
SART*3800.Description: This is an independent study course based on  Studio Art-related practical experience.  Evaluation will be based on assignments related  to work duties. Written proposals, signed by the  supervisor and a faculty member, must be  submitted to the Director for the School for  approval by the last day of course selection in  the Fall (for Winter) or Winter (for the  following Summer or Fall).
SART*3800.Restriction: Registration is limited to students registered in  the Art History or Studio Art specializations  with an average of 70% in all ARTH and SART  course attempts. Instructor consent  required.
SART*3800.Department: School of Fine Art and  Music
SART*3800.Requisites:
3.00 credits in Studio Art
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

SART*3900.Title: SART*3900 Experiential Learning II (0.5 Credits)
SART*3900.Description: This course provides students with an opportunity  to continue the workplace or activity begun in  SART*3800 in greater depth, or to experience a  new work/study situation. Evaluation will be  based on assignments related to work duties.  Written proposals, signed by the supervisor and a  faculty member, must be submitted to the Director  for the School for approval by the last day of  course selection in the Fall (for Winter) or  Winter (for the following Summer or Fall)  semester.
SART*3900.Restriction: Registration is  limited to students registered in the Art History  or Studio Art specializations with an average of  80% in all ARTH and SART course attempts.  Instructor consent required.
SART*3900.Department: School of Fine Art and Music
SART*3900.Requisites:
SART*3800 and 3.50 credits in Studio Art
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

SART*4700.Title: SART*4700 Photography III (0.5 Credits)
SART*4700.Description: This course provides students with the opportunity to generate and complete a self-directed or collaborative body of work. Students will explore various approaches to historical and contemporary modes of photography, with an emphasis on experimental, hybrid, and material-based approaches to the medium. An emphasis will be placed on conceptual development, exploring the interaction of formal and representational concerns within the practice of photography.
SART*4700.Restriction: Registration is limited to students registered in the Studio Art Major with an average of 70% in all ARTH and SART course attempts. This is a Priority Access Course. Some restrictions may apply during some time periods.
SART*4700.Department: School of Fine Art and Music
SART*4700.Requisites: 1 of SART*3600, SART*3750, (SART*2610, SART*3470)    - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

SART*4810.Title: SART*4810 Experimental Studio III (0.5 Credits)
SART*4810.Description: This course will consist of thematic projects  that elaborate on issues and practices that are  timely and significant to contemporary art. In a  context of critical reading, writing, class  exercise and discussion - students will be  encouraged to consider various forms and media to  realize their ideas. Students will continue  developing their technical skills in video and  sound production and are encouraged to explore  such forms as collage, assemblage, the artist  book and/or multiple, performance, social  practice art, interventions, and other  "post-studio" and experimental studio strategies.
SART*4810.Restriction: Registration is limited to  students registered in the Studio Art Major with  an average of 70% in all ARTH and SART course  attempts. This is a Priority Access Course. Some  restrictions may apply during some time  periods.
SART*4810.Department: School of Fine Art and  Music
SART*4810.Requisites:
1 of SART*3770, SART*4660, SART*4670
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

SART*4900.Title: SART*4900 Critical Practices: Studio Art (1 Credits)
SART*4900.Description: This capstone Studio Art course is an advanced and specialized program that encourages individual studio work, interdisciplinary and collaboration, and the development of independent study strategies. Students undertake a major self-directed project, preparing them for graduate school and professional pursuits in the Arts. While primarily self-directed, weekly classes include seminars, lectures and student presentations with a focus on contemporary art.
SART*4900.Restriction: Restricted to SART majors with an average of 70% in all ARTH and SART course attempts.
SART*4900.Department: School of Fine Art and  Music
SART*4900.Requisites: 2 of SART*4090, SART*4200, SART*4300, SART*4410, SART*4700, SART*4810   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

SART*4910.Title: SART*4910 Independent Studio (1 Credits)
SART*4910.Description: This capstone course emphasizes individual studio work, interdisciplinary collaboration, and independent study strategies by completing a major self-directed project. The course also includes seminars on professional skills for artists and concludes with a group exhibition organized by participants.
SART*4910.Restriction: Restricted to SART majors with an average of 70% in all ARTH and SART course attempts.
SART*4910.Department: School of Fine Art and  Music
SART*4910.Requisites: 2 of SART*4090, SART*4200, SART*4300, SART*4410, SART*4700, SART*4810   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

SOAN*2112.Title: SOAN*2112 Classical Theory (0.5 Credits)
SOAN*2112.Description: Second part of the two-semester course  SOAN*2111/2. This course explores the origins and  early development of sociological theory in its  classical and early contemporary traditions. When  you select it you must select SOAN*2111 in the  Fall semester and SOAN*2112 in the Winter  semester. A grade will not be assigned to  SOAN*2111 until SOAN*2112 has been completed.
SOAN*2112.Requisites:
SOAN*2111
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

SOAN*2120.Title: SOAN*2120 Introductory Methods (0.5 Credits)
SOAN*2120.Description: A general introduction to the process of social  research emphasizing research design, techniques  of data collection, analysis and interpretation  of research results.
SOAN*2120.Restriction: Restricted to students in ANTH, ANTH:C, BECN, CJPP, CJPP:C, IDS, IDS:C, JLS, JLS:C, BOH, BOH:C, SOC, BAG.ARTS
SOAN*2120.Requisites: 1 of ANTH*1150, IDEV*1000, SOC*1100, SOC*1500   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

SOAN*2290.Title: SOAN*2290 Identities & Cultural Diver (0.5 Credits)
SOAN*2290.Description: An examination of the interrelationships among  Canadian ethnic, racial and linguistic groups  including their locations in the Canadian mosaic.
SOAN*2290.Requisites:
ANTH*1150 or SOC*1100
   - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

SOAN*3070.Title: SOAN*3070 Qualitative & Observational M (0.5 Credits)
SOAN*3070.Description: Non-quantitative techniques in social research  including participant observation, unobtrusive  methods, case studies and interviewing.
